content.question: In an experiment, a student applies a net force to the edge of a disk for <math alttext="10 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student may change the magnitude and the direction of the force at any time in the experiment. A graph of the net torque exerted on the edge of the disk as a function of time is shown. After observing the graph, the student concludes that the angular momentum of the disk has not changed. Does the graph support the studentâ€™s conclusion? Justify your answer.

choices.label: Yes, because the change in the net torque from <math alttext="0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="10 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is zero.

Yes, because the slope of the curve of the graph from <math alttext="0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="5 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> has the same magnitude but opposite sign as the slope of the curve from <math alttext="5 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="10 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

No, because the area bound by the curve and the horizontal axis from <math alttext="0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="10 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is not zero.
No, because the graph cannot be used to determine how the angular momentum has changed.

content.answer: No, because the area bound by the curve and the horizontal axis from <math alttext="0 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="10 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is not zero.

unit.text: 6: Energy and Momentum of Rotating Systems

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
